loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is 49 years old and she resides in the village of Antagan, Tumauini, Isabela. She is married to Rodante S., 50 years old, whose occupation is farming. They are blessed with a child named Exequil. Lolita is wishing to send him to college someday by patiently maintaining her store to earn a daily income.

Lolita also manages a hog-raising business aside from her store. Her son is now a high school student. To further meet their needs, she would like to borrow an additional capital of PHP 7,000 that she can use in her store.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Iriel

texts.en:
Iriel T. is from the village of Militar, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 25 years old. Iriel is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Iriel owns and operates a business venture in the services sector operating transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating pedicab transport services. Iriel has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Iriel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Iriel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase an additional vehicle for the business. Iriel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to repair their existing vehicle for better service. This will be the third loan taken out by Iriel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Dam's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Dam Y. is the group leader for five members who all live in Chuos village in Takeo province. She is a vegetable middle-woman in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more vegetables to re-sell to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Lin Un, is a farmer who owns a piece of land where he cultivates rice. Mrs. Dam Y. is 44 years old and the mother of three children who are enrolled in the local school.

All the members in this group loan have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan's term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: purchasing more vegetables to re-sell

loans.name: Davaachimeg

texts.en:
Davaachimeg is 31 years old and lives with her husband and infant in Bayanzurkh, an eastern district of Mongolia's capital city, Ulaanbaatar.

Davaachimeg started her business in 2004 by selling boots at Narantuul, Ulaanbaatar's largest outdoor market. She has since changed her business to selling second-hand clothes that are imported from South Korea. Over the years she has gained much selling experience and her business is successful. She focuses on being very responsive to customer's demands, thus her goods don't sit long in her stall.

Davaachimeg's husband drives a taxi between UB and Choir, a busy town in southeast Mongolia, and helps his wife out at the market in his free time. Her sister also helps out by watching the baby for them when they are busy with work. For the future, Davaachimeg says "From my business' profits I'm going to start saving for my baby's future. Also, we want to purchase a bigger car." She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more goods.

loans.use: loan to purchase more second-hand clothing

loans.name: Nurjan's Group

texts.en:
The group’s leader, Nurjan, is forty-nine. She has raised three children. Her two daughters are married and live separately. Her son, 20, serves in the army.

Nurjan’s husband works as a director of rayon’s movie directorate. As for Nurjan, she is a housewife. However, even staying at home and doing her regular housewife’s duties; Nurjan manages to earn some money by selling milk. She sells up to ten liters daily, which allows her to make fifty dollars a month. It is a sizable amount of money, considering that they once invested just seventy dollars in buying a cow. And taking into account twenty years of a housewife’s life, it is largely due to these humble earnings of hers and of course her husband’s serious job that they have been able to refurnish their house, buy new domestic equipment, give their children a proper education and build a building opposite their house.

Nurjan has decided to diversify her daily routine by keeping sheep. She intends to fatten them and resell them. To do this, she is in need of a loan. Among her near-future plans is to marry off her son and build a new house.

Kamchybek, 37, is engaged in cattle breeding. He has a wife and three children. Even though his wife sells milk and thus contributes to the family’s budget, Kamchybek’s earnings are barely enough to support the whole family. He hopes to get a loan to buy materials for building a new shed.

Kalima, 57, is a mother of three children. Her spouse is a math teacher at school. Ten years ago, they bought a calf. Since then, Kalima has been selling milk. Kalima’s long-time dream has been to have a new bedroom suite. As Kalima earns a little, this loan might enable her dream to come true.

Asylkul, 52, is married. She has brought up four children. Currently she sells milk, making 85 dollars a month and otherwise stays at home. Her husband is a driver. Several years ago, she bought two lambs. After selling them Asylkul bought a calf and raised it. She needs a loan to buy five sheep.

====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy 5 sheep to fatten them and resell later

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
La señora Yolanda, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Los Eucaliptos”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 49 años, 03 hijos 01 que aun dependen de ella.

Su carácter emprendedor y el amor a su familia le motivaron a iniciar su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes que poco a poco fue aumentando y ganando experiencia en este tipo de actividad, haciéndose muy conocida y querida entre sus clientes.  
En la actualidad tiene sus clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su bodega a comprar donde cuenta con todo lo que el ama de casa necesita y es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con alegría y entusiasmo. 

Con el préstamo de S/ 2,000.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Anhela convertir su bodega en un minimarket y manifiesta que lo va a hacer realidad  porque es una mujer que cuando se propone algo lo cumple.

loans.use: Comprará abarrotes, para aumentar sus productos.

loans.name: Gunjilmaa

texts.en: D. Gunjilmaa is 41 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  In 2000, she moved her family to the city in the hope of finding better opportunities and improving their life. In her previous home of Govisumber province in southeastern Mongolia, Gunjilmaa worked as a salesperson at a local grocery store. Upon settling in Ulaanbaatar, she and her husband started a clothes selling business out of a stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in the city. Since then, their business has grown steadily and they have used their profits to open a second stall at the market. Today, their business has capital that exceeds 1.5 million tugrugs (approx. $1,036 USD) and operates with a profit margin of 30-40%. In the future, Gunjilmaa hopes to provide her children, who all currently attend  secondary school, with a quality education. She dreams that they will become well educated and important people for Mongolia. She is requesting a 2million tugrug (approx. $1,381 USD) loan to purchase more clothing goods to sell as her busy season is fast approaching.

loans.use: to purchase more clothing goods

loans.name: Mrs. Sorn Yoem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people living in Sam Raong village in TaK. province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. S. Y. is the 61-year-old village bank president. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Ben Ban, is a village chief. He is also a farmer who owns a piece of land where he cultivates rice. In this plantation, he faces an obstacle because his field is infertile. Thus, Mrs. S. Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make the crop more productive. She has a child who is a farmer who helps the father work. (Mrs. Sambou H. did not come to take the loan but her husband did, so he is in the picture instead of her.)   

Thirteen members in this group loan have end-of-term loans and the other has a monthly payment loan. EoT borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to support the field

loans.name: Meerim's Group

texts.en:
Meerim, 27, is the leader of this group. She and her husband work at a dry-cleaners' and both of her daughters go to elementary school. However, Meerim’s long working day does not only include dry-cleaning. As any wife, living in rural area she keeps a household and busies herself raising two sweeties. She has experience in keeping cattle. In the past they kept some cattle, but had to sell the livestock as they needed money to make a repair on their house. Then, on one of their daughter’s birthday their relatives made a present: gave them a calf.

Currently, they are engaged in making a repair in their home. They have already bought new furniture and routine repairs are about to be over. However, there is a problem for almost every family living in Kyrgyz village. Last year, the drastic reduction of water levels in the Toktogul reservoir led to failure in capability of the Toktogul hydropower station to provide sufficient electricity for the population. The Government cut off 3-phase current for all households around the country, and people living in houses had to heat their homes with coal. Meerim’s family was among them.

This year they are planning to stock up on coal in advance, since the situation with allowing usage of 3-phase current is still uncertain. Meerim needs a loan to purchase three tons of coal and with the rest of the loan buy an armored door. As a matter of fact, Meerim and her husband have many plans ahead: finish repairs, buy two cows, a car and build a building and a shed for cattle.

Meerim's partners are Aiganysh, Mairamkul, Tamara, and Eliza. Only Eliza is 22 and single. The rest of them are in their mid 40s, married and have two to three children each. Eliza works in a TV station as a manager. She needs a loan to buy sand-blocks for building a fence around her house. Aiganysh needs a loan to buy fireboard and chipboard for her ceiling. Mairamkul needs a loan to buy plastic windows and hay for cattle. Tamara needs a loan to buy hay and a refrigerator.

====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase three tons of coal and buy an armored door for their house

loans.name: Ainura's Group

texts.en:
Ainura is the leader of this group. She is a dentist. It is quite ironic, that, being surrounded by men (her husband and two sons), she is sole breadwinner for her family as her husband is temporarily unemployed and her two sons are a college student and a high school student respectively.

After she graduated from medical academy, Ainura started working and began saving her earnings. In the process of gaining experience, she already had a firm determination to open her own office. It took her many years of hard work, perseverance and patience until she was able to save US$ 1500. At last she accomplished that and opened a dental office and even bought necessary appliances and equipment.

So, for three years, she has been her own boss. Now she makes US$ 500 a month. Since any loan is a quick access to get what you need, Ainura has decided to get a loan to buy photo-filling equipment. Ainura has some far-reaching plans for making her dental room one of the best in the local area by creating service system for clients and buying high quality materials for dental treatment.

Ainura’s partners are: Dilbarbyu, Syinat and Nargiza. Dilbarbyu, 47, is divorced. Her three daughters and son being married live separately and little daughter goes to school. To make a living she sells cigarettes, mineral water and apples. Dilbarbyu needs a loan to purchase more goods and increase her turnover.

Syinat, a widow of 44, has two daughters. She has her own office/shop, where she provides minor services: opening foreign pages, loading units for cell phones, Xerox. Syinat needs a loan to buy a computer. She wants to provide typing and other computer services.

Nargiza, 23, is married, a mother of one child. She raises sheep and sells milk. Her husband is an odd-job worker on a construction site. Nargiza hopes to get a loan to buy a milch cow. She wants to earn more money from selling milk to save it for building a new shed.

====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. loans.use: to buy photo-filling equipment to improve the quality of the services provided

loans.name: Mrs. Mom Sar Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan which consists of twenty people is located in Pou Roung village in TaK. province. Mrs. Mom S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a recyclables collector. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more recyclable products to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Chiv Kha, is a motor taxi driver. Mrs. Mom S. is 38 years old and the mother of three children who are attending the local school.

Fifteen members in this group loan have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. The EoT borrowers are not required to pA. any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repA. portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: purchasing more recyclable products

loans.name: Kem

texts.en:
Kem L., age 50, is a widow and has six children. She lives with her children in Takeo Province. To make a living, she is involved in a business selling fruit and Cambodian traditional cake, typically earning approximately US $12 per day. The family is also assisted by three of her children who are currently employed in a local garment factory and a private company with a reasonable income for their living and to support the family.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, L. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, L. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $800 to purchase a motorbike, a purchase that she sees a great opportunity for one of her children to operate a business as a motor-taxi driver. (L. is pictured with her son in the photo.)

loans.use: motorbike purchase

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao N., age 36, is married and has six children. She lives with her husband in Takeo Province. To make a living, she is engaged in a small business of producing Cambodian traditional cake (bananas with rice wrapped together in banana leaves), typically earning a gross income of US $4.00 per day. Her husband also plays a major role in the family finances. To generate a better source of income for his family, he is engaged in a business transporting palm sugar to sell with an income of US $9 per day. The family is also assisted by two of her children who are currently employed in a local garment factory.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, N. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most.

In light of the country's economic difficulties, N. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer, a purchase that she sees as a great opportunity to collect coconuts from her village and other nearby places and sell them off at a fair but profitable price.

loans.use: purchasing a motorbike and a trailer

loans.name: Mr. Moa Soeun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eighteen people living in Preaek Ta Kaev village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mr. Moa S. is the 40-year-old village bank president. He is a fisherman. His wife, Mrs. M. San, is a fish seller in the local market, selling her husband's catch. Now Mr. Moa S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fishnets to add to his fishing gear. He has six children, one of whom is a security guard in a garment factory while four are enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study.

Five members in this group loan have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. The EoT borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more fishnets to add to his fishing gear

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa J. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 54 years old. Josefa is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Josefa owns and operates a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling eggs in the local community and local market. Josefa has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In February 2008, Josefa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josefa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Josefa is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Josefa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

texts.en:
The village bank loan, which consists of nineteen people, is located in Preak Ta Kaev village in Kandal province. Mr. San K. is the village bank president and has been selected by the members. He is a fisherman. Since his fisH. is doing well, he wants to expand it by purchasing more fishnets. His wife, Mrs. Chi Hun, is a farmer who owns a small lake to cultivate lotus. Mr. San K. is 53 years old and the father of four children, two of whom are fishermen while the other is attending the local school. Mr. Arn A. does not come to take a loan but his wife does, so she is shown in the picture. 

Seven members in this group loan have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. loans.use: By purchasing more fishnets.

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San T., age 43, is married and has two children. She lives with her husband in Takeo Province. She is a farmer, typically earning a small income of US $0.50 per day. Her husband generates the primary source of income for his family as a motor-taxi driver earning US $8 per day. The two children also assist the family by receiving fair income through employment in a local garment factory and a private company.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This has made it a difficult economic year for much of the country, T. included, with the country's economic struggles always seeming to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, T. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $1200 in order to purchase a motorbike which would provide a great opportunity for one of her children to get to work faster and easier.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en:
Chhem K., age 45, is married and has two children. She lives with her husband in Takeo Province. To make a living, she and her husband are engaged in the agriculture sector as rice field farmers, typically earning collectively US $1.50 per day. However, the family is assisted mainly by one of her children who is involved in a business with a gross income of US $42 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, K. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, K. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike, a purchase that she sees a great opportunity for one of her children to transport livestock collected from his village and other nearby places to sell in the city.

loans.use: motorbike purchase

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina M. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 60-years old and married with five adult children. Josefina owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from buying and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Josefina has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Josefina joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josefina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Josefina is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be her fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase fish

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Nelma

texts.en:
Nelma Y. is from the village of Pob. Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 55-years old and married with two adult children. Nelma owns and operates a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing general clothing services to local community members. Nelma has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 7,000.00 PHP a month.

In 2007, Nelma joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Nelma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional equipment and tools such as needles and threads. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Nelma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About PMPC:

The Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Era

texts.en:
Era M. is from the village of Caluya, Sapang Dalaga Mis. Occ.. She is 52 years old. Era is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Era owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling variety of food products in the local community. Era has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Era joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Era has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Era is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Era from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca Y. is from the village of Zone 2, San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 44 years old, and is married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Rebecca owns and operates a business in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Rebecca has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Rebecca joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rebecca has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. She is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be her fifth from HSPFI. Rebecca plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income and support her children's education.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel is a food vendor in her village in San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela. She is now requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders that she will use as additional capital for her business. Her weekly income of PHP 1,000 is just enough to meet the needs of their family. Because she wants to become a progressive entrepreneur in the business, she needs capital to make it grow.

Maricel is 30 years old and she already has two children. Her husband is a farmer and he helps her in the business when he has extra time. Their eldest child, Marjolaine, is currently in fourth grade in elementary, and Mark Jay is just 2 years old. Maricel wants to give the best for her two children for their future.

loans.name: Rosielyn

texts.en:
“If you are thrifty, you will never be empty in times of emergency”, says Rosielyn as she always remember.   She is vendor of fish, meat and frozen foods.  She is the responsible wife of Micheal and they have four children and they live in Barangay Sto. Domingo, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. They want their children to be successful in the future by providing them with the right education.  Despite the economic crisis, the couple helps each other to earn a living for them to be able to send their children to school and survive their battle against poverty.
 
Her husband is presently working abroad as an Industrial Electrician while Rosielyn manages her small business.  She wanted her business to improve so she can help her husband in meeting the growing needs of their family.  She is now requesting a loan amounting to PHP14, 000 as additional capital. Through her patience and sacrifices, Rosielyn is able to earn around PHP6, 000 monthly income that is really was of big help in their daily needs. According to Rosielyn, she will do her best for her family and become a responsible wife and mother.
