Vivian has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Vivian is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Vivian from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income and support her children's education. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: May Flor

texts.en:
May Flor believes that “if there’s a will, there is always a way”. She knows that life is getting harder now a days that is why she strives hard to earn from their motorcycle transport business. May Flor has able to finished a degree on education but due to lack of job opportunities, she only end up as a teacher in the Day Care Center in their village and she was given a monthly honorarium salary that comes from their village fund.  To have additional capital, she decided to sell frozen foods in the afternoon after her class.  

May Flor is 32 years old.  Her husband is maintaining a passenger tricycle in their village in Calamagui 1st, Ilagan, Isabela. They have two children: Avelino and John. Avelino is already two years old while her youngest is just two months old. She is wishing for a brighter future for their children through their diligence. 

At the moment, she wanted to help her husband in maintaining their tricycle.  With this she is requesting to avail a loan of PHP8,000.00.  She also plan to use some of the loan for her frozen food business for bigger profit.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Doljinjav

texts.en: Doljinjav is a 41-year-old businesswoman who lives with her family in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. Her three oldest children are university students and the youngest is a secondary school student. Doljinjav  operates a mobile retail trading business in her town. With the help of her husband, who is a driver, she uses the family car to travel throughout the countryside selling goods to local farmers. In addition to her mobile business, Doljinjav also purchases dairy products from the farmers to sell at the local market or sometimes in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. Doljinjav started her business in 2000 and has achieved success. Since she started, her business capital has increased to more than five times its starting amount. She uses the business' profits to pay her children's university tuition, which is very expensive for the average rural family in Mongolia. Doljinjav is a very hard-working and open-minded person and says, "My dream is to one day have my own grocery store." She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (approx. $690 USD) loan to purchase more goods for her mobile trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more goods

loans.name: Beknazar

texts.ru: Холназаров Бекназар проживает в районе Руми. Возраст 27 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. По специальности Бекназар более 5 лет работал "строителем". Вот более 2 лет занимается сельским хозяйством. Он выращивает и продает на рынке бахчевые растения. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота, т.е. для посева нового урожая.
texts.en:
Beknazar H. lives in the Rumy district. He is 27 years old, married and has 5 children. Beknazar spent over 5 years working in his profession as a construction worker. He has been involved in agriculture for over 2 years now. He grows melon plants and sells them at a market. He is requesting a loan to increase product turnover, i.e. to plant the new crop.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Planting new crop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dulzora

texts.en:
Dulzora B. is from the village of Tumpagon in Cagayan de Oro City. She is 64 years old. Dulzora is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Dulzora runs a food stall where she sells bread and coffee. Dulzora has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Dulzora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dulzora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Dulzora is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will Dulzora's 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income and support her children's education. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Dulamjinkhuu

texts.en:
S. Dulamjinkhuu is 49 years old. She lives with her husband and three children in Arkhangai Province in central Mongolia. Her husband works as an agriculture specialist for the province governor's office, her middle son and daughter are university students, and her youngest daughter is a high school student. She also has a son who currently lives and works in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. 

Dulamjinkhuu operates a dairy trading business from a rented stall at the local market in her town. She purchases the dairy goods from local farmers in the countryside and sells them at her stall. 

Dulamjinkhuu started her dairy business in 1992 with capital of 200,000 tugrugs (approx. $138 USD). Due to her hard work,  she has made her business very successful and has used the profits to greatly improve her family's quality of life. Today, her business capital exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (approx. $1,380 USD). Dulamjinkhuu's dream is to provide her children with a quality education so that they can become smart and improve their lives. In the future, Dulamjinkhuu said, "I always dream of owning my own comfortable work place." 

She is requesting a loan of 3.5 million tugrug to purchase more goods for her dairy business.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for her dairy business

loans.name: Rano

texts.ru: Рано Асоева проживает в районе Руми. Возраст 45 лет. Вдова, имеет 3 детей. Рано более 5 лет занимается бизнесом, т.е. торговлей. Она ходит по кишлакам и селам, торгует одеждой. В основном: полотенцем, бельем, платками и т.д. Кредит просит для закупа нового ассортимента.
texts.en:
Rano A. lives in the Rumy district. She is 45 years old, a widow and has 3 children. Rano has been involved in sales for over 5 years. She goes to kishlaks and villages and sells clothing. She primarily sells towels, undergarments, scarves and etc. Rano is requesting a loan to purchase new merchandise selection.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of new merchandise selection

loans.name: Janibichi Group

texts.en:
Anna is a member of the Janibichi borrower group in Mwanjelwa,mbeya ,she is 44 years old woman,she is widowed and a mother of 1 child.Her child is aged 16 years.

Anna started her own food business selling tomatoes,banana 6 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 250,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is anna`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more Tomatoes,banana,onions.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Anna hopes to save money and expand her business.

Faraja,Ambwene are another member of the same borrower group,they also requested loan amount of 200,000Tsh in order to expand their business.

loans.use: To buy more banan,onions,tomatoes

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa R. is from the village of Tumpagon in Cagayan de Oro City. She is 29 years old. Marissa is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Marissa sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Marissa has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Marissa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marissa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Marissa is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Marissa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of her family and support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Javzandulam

texts.en:
Javzandulam J. is 31 years old and lives with her 3 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. All three of her children, two sons and a daughter, currently attend universities. 

Javzandulam sells sausage and meat products from a stall at Narantuul, Ulaanbaatar's largest outdoor market. Javzandulam started her business in 2001 and has since found much success. She currently runs the business with the help of her children, who have provided much support since their father passed away. Javzandulam is a very hard-working and responsible businesswoman and hopes to expand her business in the future. 

With the profits from her business, she has been able to build a new house for her family and pay for her children's education. Her dream is for her  3 children to become highly educated people. She is requesting a 1,750,000 tugrug loan to purchase supplies and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies and expand her business

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.ru: Насиба Акобирова проживает в районе Руми. Возраст 22 года. Насиба свободна, детей не имеет, живет вместе с родителями. По специальности Насиба "швея". Она более 3 лет занимается пашивом одежды у себя на дому. Она также берет учеников и обучает их (платно). Кредит просит для покупки новой швейной машинки.
texts.en:
Nasiba A. lives in the Rumy region. She is 22 years old. Nasiba is free and does not have children, she lives with her parents. Nasiba is a seamstress by profession. She has been sewing clothing at home for more than three years. She also accepts students and teaches for a fee. She is asking for a loan to buy a new sewing machine.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 from Kiva lenders to use as additional business capital for her general store. She knows that the loan will help with the progress of her store and that it will somehow lead to progressive living for her family. 

Norma is 56 years old and he is married to Alfredo, a farmer. They are blessed with three children. Their youngest child is still in school, but the other two have already graduated from college. Norma borrowed a loan because she wanted her business to grow. She is hoping that, with the help of Kiva, all her goals in life will gradually become reality.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Ryan

texts.en:
Ryan is living a simple life in Sto. Domingo, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya with her family. He just graduated from high school in March 2009 at the age of 30. He believes that one is never too old enough to pursue his studies. However, he could not continue on to college due to lack of financial resources. Instead, he will help his parents cultivate their rice field and vegetable farm. He wanted to save for his future family. But, in the meantime, he will help his parents to earn a living. 

They get their major source of income from farming. At the moment, Ryan is now cultivating their farmland twice a year by planting rice and a variety of vegetables. He is now asking for a loan of PHP36,000 from Kiva lenders. This amount will be used to maintain their rice field and to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers, insecticide, and labor fees for farm laborers. Some will be used for food and snacks. He hopes that lenders will trust him with business capital for his farm.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
L. Oyun is a 37-year-old businesswoman who lives with her husband and three children in Arkhangai Province in Central Mongolia. Her oldest son and daughter both attend a local secondary school, but her youngest son has not yet reached school age. 

Oyun operates a small butcher shop in her town where she sells meat to local residents from a stall at the local market. Her husband, who works as a stoker, helps in his free time. Oyun started her business in 2000 with capital of 300,000 tugrugs (approx. $207 USD). Because of her hard work and strong customer service skills, her business has been successful and her current business capital exceeds 1,300,000 tugrugs (approx. $898 USD).  In the future, she hopes to open a second stall in the market to expand her business.  

She says, "I would like to have my own workplace and fund my children's education."  She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 tugrugs to purchase more meat.

loans.use: To purchase more whole animal meats

loans.name: Saidat

texts.en:
Saidat is a 40-year-old married woman with four children aged 18 - 23 years. All of her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she lives with eight people. Saidat takes care of two additional family members. There is electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. 

She lives and works in semi-urban area where she is a tailor in one of Kampala's streets. She incurs extra transportation costs from home to work. Saidat owns a sewing machine and is a tailor on Luwum Street. She attends to 4 customers a day on average and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family, and rent both at home and at work. She has been in this business for the last five years.

Saidat has been with MCDT for five years and is borrowing her eighth loan with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more clothes to resell. Saidat hopes to see her business grow and to own rental rooms and a permanent home.

loans.use: To buy more clothing

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie S. is from the village of Zone 2 in Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 29 years old. Jessie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jessie runs a sari-sari (variety) retail store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Jessie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Jessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jessie is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be Jessie's 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Tsend

texts.en: Tsend is a 55 years old, retiree, who lives with her two adult sons in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. From an early age her sons took much interest in automobiles. They both learned how do drive and became skilled in auto repair. In 2007, taking advantage of her sons' skills, Tsend opened a tire repair service shop with them. Currently, the boys operate the tire repair shop during the day and drive taxis in the evenings.  Over the last two years, business has become very stable. They have developed a good reputation in their community and have many regular customers. Tsend started the business with capital of  100,000 tugrugs (approx. 70 USD). Today their business capital exceeds 900,000 tugrugs (approx. 620 USD).  Tsend is a very open-minded person and says, "I would like to improve and expand my business. Also, I want to see my sons get married." She is requesting a 1,300,000 tugrugs (approx. $898 USD) to purchase more supplies for her repair shop.

loans.use: to purchase more supplies for her auto repair shop.

loans.name: Tsendsuren

texts.en: Tsendsuren T. is a single woman who lives in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She has been living for the last three years with her brother in a ger (Mongolian nomadic tent) in a yard she owns. Tsendsuren operates a small retail trade selling religious items in her town. She first gained experience working as a salesperson at her sister's store before going out on her own. Tsendsuren started her business in 2003 with capital of 300,000 tugrugs. She has built her business to a stable level and attributes its success to her strong selling and communication skills. Today, her business capital exceeds 900,000 tugrugs.  Tseendsuren's dreams of one day opening a big store in her town and said: “I work with the aim to help my brother so that he receives a good education and has a good life like other people do”. She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (approx. $1040 USD) loan to purchase more religious items for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more religious items for her business.

loans.name: Ilem B Group

texts.en:
Claudina is a member of the Ilem B borrower group in Mwanjelwa,Mbeya,she is 28 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children.her children are aged 4 and 2 years.

Claudina started her own cafe business selling food 4 years ago,she works 11 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Claudina first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice,sugar,tomatoes for her business.


with the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Claudina hopes to save money,pay school fees and expand her business.

Felisiana is another member of the same borrower she also requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice,cooking oil,sugar

loans.name: Tsogtbayar

texts.en:
Tsogtbayar T. lives with his wife and 3 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His oldest child currently attends elementary school and his youngest two children have not yet reached school age. 

Tsogtbayar sells shoes in his hometown with the help of his wife. He sells shoes from a rented stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in the city. Tsogtbayar started his business in 2004 and has gained much experience as a businessman. He has excelled as a good salesman. 

Tsogtbayar attributes the success of his business to his hardworking attitude and good business sense. For the future he says ''I want to improve and expand my business so that I can build a house for my family.''  He is requesting a 2 million tugrug  (~ $1400 USD) loan to purchase supplies and expand his business..

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and expand his business.

loans.name: Cossy

texts.en:
Cossy is a 22 year married with two children aged 11 months and 4 fours.  One of her children goes to school. She resides and owns a two roomed house where she is staying with three people. Cossy takes care of additional family members There is electricity and piped water at her home.  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area where she deals in cold drinks and refreshments.  She incurs extra transport costs from and to shopping. Cossy sells to an average of 10 customers a day and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees. Feeding the family She has been in this business for the last five years Harriet has been with MCDT for years servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes.  Cossy is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a rental rooms 
 

.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and soda

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina is 50 years old. She is married to Rodolfo, 52 years old, and they both work as farmers. Her husband manages their farm lot while she is responsible for maintaining their hog-raising business. Aside from that, they are also engaged in a tricycle-transport business for additional capital.

Florentina hopes to borrow PHP 15,000 from Kiva lenders to further maintain their motorcycle and also to use for their hogs.

They have three children: the twins, Mary Ann and Mary Jane, are already college graduates but still unemployed, The youngest is Mary Joy and she is still studying. Florenina hopes that all her children will someday have a stable job for their future families. She wants them to not have to experience the difficulties in life that she and her husband have been through. She just hopes that the amount she is requesting from Kiva will become fruitful as she invests it in their motorcycle and hogs.

loans.use: To maintain their motorcycle and their hogs

loans.name: Laure Damienne

texts.fr: Laure Damienne est née vers 1969. Laure Damienne est mariée et est mère de deux enfants. Laure Damienne est couturière de formation. La famille vit à Cocotomey, non loin de Cotonou, Capitale Économique  de la République du Bénin.  Laure Damienne vend des articles de mercerie dans sa boutique en face de continental Bank Bénin de Cocotomey. C’est au Nigeria, État voisin du Bénin, que Laure Damienne achète ses articles. Laure Damienne demande ce prêt d’ALIDé pour accroître son capital et satisfaire la demande sans cesse grandissante de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Laure Damienne is born around 1969. She is married and the mother of two children. Laure Damienne is a trained seamstress. The family lives in Cocotomey, close to Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Laure Damienne sells sewing supplies in her shop in front of the Continental Bank Benin of Cocotomey. Laure Damienne buys her goods in Nigeria, a neighboring state of Benin and is requesting this loan from ALIDE in order to increase her capital and to meet the ever growing request of her clientele.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sewing supplies

loans.name: Ilem B Group

texts.en:
Yusta is a member of the Ilem B borrower group in Mwanjelwa,Mbeya,she is 24 years old woman,she is widowed and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 3 and 1 years.

Yusta started her own shop business selling rice,sugar,salts 3 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Yusta`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more shop commodities.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Yusta hopes to save money and expand her business.

Bahati is another member of the same borrower group,she also requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities like rice,sugar for her shop

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina C. is a business manager of her own. Since she lives in the island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines, she is in the fishing business. She is hardworking and full of energy in her search for a better life. She is married to Binedicto who is 37 years old and a passenger boat driver. She is mother to three princesses; all of whom are still dependents.

In 2006 her dream of escaping poverty led her to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with the hope of having access to capital for her business. Previously, she was involved in producing bamboo products such as sets, sofa and other products. But that was laborious and the raw materials were expensive. That experience had driven her to shift her business into fish farming. Since she is living on the island, they are surrounded with water and the major source of income of the villagers is fishing. The village is well known to other towns as a source of fish.

For two years Carolina has been running the fish farming business and she is happy to say that the business brings her enough proceeds to sustain her family. She is happy to see her business growing. Now on her 5th loan, she is asking for 25,000 pesos to pay for 2 bundles of fish nets, 100 pieces of bamboo, nails, and fingerlings; everything needed for a fish cage.

She hopes that her business will grow and is looking forward to having additional fish cages and sending her children to school until they can finish college and find jobs.

loans.use: To make and stock a fish cage

loans.name: Cossy

texts.en:
Cossy is a 22-year-old married woman with two children aged 11 months and 4 years, one of whom goes to school. She resides in and owns a two-roomed house where she lives with three people and also takes care of additional family members. There is electricity and piped water at her home and the family gets three meals a day.

Cossy resides and works in a semi-urban area where she deals in cold drinks and refreshments. She works six days a week and has been in this business for the last five years. She sells to an average of ten customers a day and sells to all categories of people. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping and her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. 

Cossy has been with MCDT for years and is servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and soda to sell. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and owning some rental rooms.

loans.use: To buy more  crates of beer and soda

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
61-year-old Asuncion and her 65-year-old husband, who is a farmer, started growing rice as a business when Asuncion inherited a piece of agricultural land from her parents seven months ago. And timely to that, Asuncion had known Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) as being the microfinance organization that lends money to women who aspire to become entrepreneurs.

Asuncion’s first loan was used to finance her rice production business. After four months, the rice was harvested and she saw that it produced profit well, and enough to finance the next season of planting.

However, Asuncion wants her business to grow. She wants to produce a hybrid quality of rice and to build her own storage room where she can store her rice after harvest. Through borrowing a larger amount from ASHI she believes that someday she will be able to finance a greater area of rice field and be able to hire laborers in their community to work on her farm.

Asuncion’s two children, who have their own source of income now, also help her during the rice planting and harvesting seasons.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seedlings for her farm

loans.name: Afi Cathérine

texts.fr: Afi Cathérine est née vers 1982. Cathérine est mariée et mère de deux enfants. La famille vit à Cocotomey, non loin de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Cathérine vend des sacs de maïs au marché de Cocotomey. C’est à Parakou au Nord du Bénin et à Adja dans le Département du Mono que Cathérine achète ses produits. Cathérine a déjà eu de prêt de la part d’ALIDé ; prêt qu’elle a bien remboursé. Cathérine sollicite encore de prêt d’ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement et accroître le volume de ses produits pour le bonheur de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Afi Cathérine was born around 1982.  She is married and the mother of two children.  The family lives in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou,  the economic capital of the Republic of Benin.  She sells sacks of corn at the Cocotomey marketplace.  Parakou in northern Benin, and Adja in Mono County, are where she buys her goods.  Cathérine has already had a loan from ALIDé that she has repaid.  She is requesting an ALIDé loan again to boost her working capital and to increase her merchandise volume for the happiness of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ten 100-kg sacks of corn

loans.name: Ilemi B Group

texts.en:
Upendois a member of the Ilemi B borrower group in Mwanjelwa,Mbeya,she is  years old woman,she is married and a mother of 3 children.Her children are aged 16,11,4 years.

Upendo started her own clothing business selling clothes 7 years ago,she works 10 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Upendo`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy Fabric clothes(kanga,vitenge)

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Upendo hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Annia is another member of the same borrower group,she also requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more vitenge,kanga

loans.name: Nathalie

texts.fr: Nathalie est née à Kouti dans le Département de l'Ouémé au Sud-Ouest du BENIN. Nathalie est mariée à Jacques, un commerçant. Nathalie est mère de 5 enfants. Nathalie vend de maïs ainsi que les condiments de sauce (tomate fraîche et en boîte, oignon, poivre, ail, gombo, sésame, piment, cube…). C’est au Nord du Bénin que Nathalie achète le maïs et l’oignon. Quant au reste des condiments de sauce, Nathalie l’achète à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. Nathalie sollicite d’ALIDé un prêt pour acheter et stocker le maïs maintenant que le prix est au plus bas.
texts.en:
Nathalie was born in Kouti in Ouémé County (southwestern Benin).  She is married to Jacques, a merchant.  Nathalie is the mother of five children.  She sells corn, as well as sauce condiments (fresh tomatoes, canned tomatoes, onions, black pepper, garlic, okra, sesame seeds, chili peppers, bouillon cubes...).  In northern Benin is where she buys corn and onions. As for the rest of the sauce condiments, these are purchased at Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin.  Nathalie is requesting a loan from ALIDé to buy and stock up on corn, now that prices are at their lowest.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn and sauce condiments

loans.name: Alona

texts.en:
Alona is 29 years old and has a one-year-old daughter named Lovely Angel. Alona is married to Sabas, a farmer in their village in Bacnor West, Roxas, Isabela. Their primary source of livelihood is farming, managed by her husband.

To help her husband in supporting the needs of their family, Alona ventured into the hog-raising business and her income from this is of big help on their farm, like purchasing farm inputs and maintaining the growth of their crops.

Alona is now requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders for the maintenance of her small business. She wants the business to grow because this will be a great help in sending their child to school. Alona never gets tired of praising God for giving her a happy family. She prays that God will continue to bless her family and her business.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Ayaba Claire

texts.fr: Ayaba Claire est née vers 1971 à Pahou dans la Commune de Ouidah au Sud du BENIN. Claire est veuve et mère de 3 enfants encore sous sa responsabilité. Claire vit avec ses enfants à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Depuis bientôt 10 ans, Claire vend des poissons frits ainsi que les condiments de sauce (tomate fraîche et en boîte, oignon, poivre, ail, gombo, sésame, piment, cube…). C’est dans une boutique sise à son domicile, que Claire vend ses produits. Claire a besoin de moyens financiers pour renforcer son capital afin de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. C’est pourquoi Claire sollicite l’appui d’ALIDé.
texts.en:
Ayaba Claire was born around 1971 in Pahou in the Township of Ouidah in the south of Benin. Claire is a widow and the mother of 3 children, all of them still her responsibility. Claire lives with her children in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin.

For almost 10 years, Claire has been selling fried fish and condiments used for sauces (fresh and tinned tomatoes, onions, pepper, garlic, okra, sesame seeds, hot peppers, Maggi cubes, etc.) She sells her products in a little shop located in her house. Claire needs to bolster her working capital so that she can better meet the needs of her clientele. This is why Claire has asked for the support of ALIDé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cartons of fish, baskets of fresh tomatoes, baskets of hot peppers, sacks of onions, and spices

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is a 38-year-old single mother of five children aged between 12 and 20 years. All her children are in school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house where she lives with five people. She also takes care of additional family members. There is electricity and piped water at her home and the family gets three meals a day.

Harriet resides and works in a semi-urban area where she deals in secondhand clothes. She has been in this business for the last five years and works six days a week. She sells to an average of ten customers a day and sells to all categories of people.

Harriet incurs extra transport costs to and from Owino market where she buys those clothes. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

Harriet has been with MCDT for six years and is servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of secondhand clothes. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and owning some rental rooms.

loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.fr: Jacqueline est née le 27 Décembre 1979 à Ouidah au Sud du BENIN. Jacqueline est mariée et mère de 2 enfants : Flora et Frédéric. Jacqueline a une cabine téléphonique qu’elle gère elle-même ainsi qu’une baraque dans laquelle elle vend des seaux, bassines et autres ustensiles en plastique. C’est devant son domicile, chez elle que Jacqueline a installé sa cabine téléphonique et sa baraque. Jacqueline a dû puiser dans son fonds de roulement pour soigner sa fille Flora qui était malade. C’est pourquoi, Jacqueline sollicite le soutien financier d’ALIDé pour renforcer son capital et maintenir son activité au bon niveau.
texts.en:
Jacqueline was born on December 27, 1979 in Ouidah in the south of Benin. Jacqueline is married and the mother of two children: Flora and Frédéric. Jacqueline has a phone booth that she manages herself, as well as a shed where she sells buckets, basins, and other plastic utensils. Jacqueline installed her phone booth and shed in front of her house. She had to draw on her working capital to care for her daughter, Flora, who was ill. That is why Jacqueline is requesting a loan to bolster her capital and keep her business running smoothly.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of buckets, basins, and kitchen utensils made of plastic

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita lives in the rural community of Sto. Domingo, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is now a widow and has sole responsibility for their only daughter, Mylene. With her patience in maintaining her hog-raising business, she was able to provide her daughter with a college education. Her daughter is now working abroad.

Perlita has been into hog-raising for many years. The business has become her partner in sending her daughter to school and in providing the needs of their family. She started with two piglets, one male and one female until they multiplies into six. Her business grows because of her hard work and dedication.

Her desire to further improve her business motivated Perlita to ask for additional capital of PHP 31,000 from Kiva lenders. She hopes that the business will someday become successful and stable to enable her daughter to decide to stay home for good.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Janibichi Group

texts.en:
Ester is a member of the B. borrower group in Mwanjelwa,Mbeya,she is 48 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 4 children.Her children are aged 25,23,20,18, and 15 years.

Ester started her own business selling local beer 5 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Ester first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Ester hopes to save money and expand her business.

Paulina,Aines another member of the same borrower group,they also requested the loan amount 200,000Tsh Each one in order to expand their own business.

loans.use: To buy more maize

loans.name: Aurenila

texts.en:
Aurenila is a 43 year old hog raiser. She is requesting to avail a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP11, 000 for the maintenance and growth of her livestock business. Aside from raising hogs, she is also into beauty service for 20 years as her alternative source of income.  Aurenila is grateful that knowing Kiva will give her a chance to improve her business.  

Aurenila is married to Alex Sr, a village councilor. They were blessed with three children: Chester, Cherry and Alex Jr. All of them are studying. She hopes someday they could finish a course in college for them to have a better future. She is a former domestic helper abroad that which, her experience abroad molded Aurenila to work harder and patient in every business undertakings to become successful.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is a member of the Itiji  05 borrower group in Itiji,mbeya she is 33 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 11 and 5.

Janeth started her own business selling animal food 6 years ago,she works 10 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 160,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Janeth first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more animal food for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Janeth hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy  more animal food

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice lives and works in a semi-urban area where she deals in secondhand clothes. She incurs extra transport costs to and from the Owino market, where she buys those clothes. Alice sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all kinds of people. She works six days a week. She has been in this business for the last five years.

Alice is a 48-year-old married woman with seven children, ages 16 to 28 years. Three of her children are in school. She owns a three-room house where she lives with nine people. Alice doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is electricity and piped water in her home. The family gets three meals a day. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

Alice has been with MCDT for five years; she is now on her tenth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of secondhand clothes. Alice wants to see her business expand and to own rooms to rent.

loans.use: To buy more bales of clothing

loans.name: Hope

texts.en:
Hope D. P. has been selling fried macaroni elbows (kropek), retail and wholesale, for almost one year. Her products are delivered to different villages of Cauayan City. She has two helpers in the business and, with their continuous support, Hope is able to earn around 5,000 PHP net income monthly.

Hope is a good mother to Cyrus, her 5-year-old son. She is married to Wilfredo, who is a tricycle operator in Cauayan City. Hope is 28 years old. Her small family lives in a simple village: Christine Village of Cauayan City. Their place is barely three kilometers away from the city proper. As her name indicates, she is full of hope! In good business partnership with her husband, they will some day win the battle against poverty.

Since Hope is earning a good income from her business, she is asking for the support of Kiva lenders to grow her business even more. She wants to borrow just 8,000 PHP. Hope is patiently maintaining her business, though it is very laborious on her part. She thinks that doing this will benefit her family in the future – especially her children.

loans.use: Additional capital for kropek business

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda runs a general store business in Christine Village in Cauayan City. She has been in this business for almost two years. Her weekly income is around 1,400 PHP which is being used as rolling capital and to meet the needs of her family – especially for the education of her children.

Rhoda is 39 years old – a simple micro entrepreneur in her own way. She is married to Leonardo, a local government employee in Angadanan, Isabela. They are blessed with three children: two are already in school while their youngest is only three years old.

Rhoda wants to borrow 8,000 PHP from Kiva lenders. This loan will be very useful for the development of her business. Rhoda is hoping that, with the support of her lenders and with perseverance, her business will grow and she will be successful.

loans.use: For a general store business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a store owner in the rural village of Pulay Luna, Isabela. She is married to Gilbert M., who is a farmer. They are blessed with a 28-year-old daughter, Virginia, who was able to graduate from high school. They now have two grandsons who bring joy to their family.

Lydia's retail business has been instrumental in supporting the needs of their family. For this reason, she wants to maintain her store. She is requesting a loan amount of 15,000 PHP to use as additional capital for her store. She hopes that the business will become more productive and fruitful in the future. Lydia also shares her main quotation in life, which is “Patience is her key to success.”

loans.use: additional capital for her store

loans.name: Cornelia

texts.en: At her age of 43, Cornelia G. patiently maintains her vegetable vending business in their Barangay. She is married to Santiago, a good and loving husband. They are gifted with two children: Jaycer and Jay - Mark. The couple lives peacefully in the rural village of Banquero, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. Her husband helps her in maintaining their vegetable production that she retails in their village and sometimes in the market. She even sells volumes of harvested vegetables to buyers in wholesale price. Cornelia wants to have continuous business to be able to support most of their family’s necessities, that’s why Cornelia is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP5, 000 as business additional capital. Moreover, her dream in life is to maintain the good health of her family to be able to comply with their responsibilities and obligations in life.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a member of the Itiji West in Itiji,Mbeya,she is 32 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 3 children.Her children are aged 15,17 and 20 years.

Joyce started her own cafe business selling food 1year ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Joyce first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities like rice,cooking oil for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,joyce hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy rice,wheat for her business

loans.name: Mrs. Long Hong Un Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-five people living in Pou Roung village in the Takeo province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Long H. U. is a 50-year-old village bank president. She is a farmer, and owns land to cultivate rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr. Kiev MoeU., is a policeman. The couple has three children, one of whom is a laborer, another is a grocer, and the third is attending the local school. Mrs. Long H. U. is applying for a loan to buy more grocery products to expand her second child’s business.

Fifteen members in this group have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. End-of-term (EoT) loans do not require principal payments until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. This type of loan allows the members to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start making payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy grocery products to expand her second child’s business.

loans.name: Baby Lou

texts.en:
Babyy Lou is a hog raiser.  but aside from that, she also helps her husband in their farm.  She also ventured into rice retailing business.  She wishes to maintain her business in order to save for the future education of their children. To do this, she needs to be very patient and accompany it with hard work. 

She is now requesting to avail a loan of PHP5, 000 from Kiva lenders for the maintenance of her hog raising and continuous development of her newly start retailing business. Baby Lou feels so blessed for having an understanding husband. They now have a child and hopefully they could provide her with her needs as she grows so with their future children. The family lives peacefully in the village of San Lorenzo Ilagan, Isabela.

loans.use: business expansion

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en:
Luciana is 60 years old and single. She owns a general store in the village of Rio Del Grande, Enrile, Cagayan. Her store is located in front of her house and it is open from 6:00 in the morning until 9:00 in the evening.

Luciana wants to borrow 5,000 PHP from Kiva lenders. She will use the loan to buy different merchandise for her store. She also sells root crops and different kinds of vegetables. The income from her business is being used to meet the needs of her family. Despite her age, Luciana is very determined to further develop her business.

loans.use: Additional capital for a store

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 42-year-old widow with five children, ages 13 to 18 years. Margaret also takes care of two additional family members. All of her children go to school. Margaret owns a small restaurant selling cold drinks and refreshments. She serves an average of 30 customers of all kinds every day. She works six days a week. She has been in this business for the last five years. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.

Margaret owns a two-room house in the semi urban area where she works. She lives there with her eight family members. There is electricity and piped water in her home. The family gets three meals a day. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

Margaret has been with MCDT for five years and is now on her eighth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of secondhand clothes. Margaret wants to see her business expand and to own rooms to rent.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of food

loans.name: Philomène

texts.fr: Philomène est mariée à Toussaint, comptable de profession. Philomène est mère de 2 enfants. Philomène est coiffeuse de profession. Mais depuis deux ans, Philomène commercialise plutôt du maïs et du piment. Philomène a déjà bénéficié d’un premier crédit de la part de ALIDé. Philomène a bien remboursé ce crédit et sollicite un deuxième crédit pour renforcer son capitale en vue d’augmenter le volume de ses produits.
texts.en:
Philomène is married to Toussaint, who is an accountant. Philomène is the mother of 2 children. She is a trained hairdresser. But for the last two years, Philomène has been selling maize and hot peppers instead.

Philomène has already received a first loan from ALIDé. She reimbursed that loan correctly and is asking for a second loan to bolster her working capital with the intention of expanding her stock.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of bags of maize and bags of hot peppers

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is a member of the Itiji West borrower group in Itiji,Mbeya,she is 29 years old woman,she is married and she cares for 2 dependents.

Sophia started her own business selling Tapes and DVD 1 years ago,she works 10 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Sophia`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 250,000 Tsh in order to buy more Tapes,DVD.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,sophia hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more Tapes, DVD for her business

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda is selling native snacks made from glutinous rice in Antagan 1st, Tumauini, Isabela. She worked as a domestic helper in Kuwait for seven years that was when her children were still young. Her salary before was just enough for her five children.  She came home without any savings so her husband decided to work abroad as a construction worker with the dream to build a small house for his family. 

Presently, Melinda and their five children lives in a very simple house. Melinda helps her husband by engaging herself into snack vending business.  She used to roam around the village selling her products.  She also sells barbecue in the afternoon and other snacks like cassava. Melinda wanted to be more productive in her enterprise so she is now asking to borrow a loan of PHP6, 000 as additional  capital. She hopes that Kiva lenders will grant her request.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Pedro Armando

texts.es: Pedro Armando O. de 36 años de edad reside en el municipio de Apopa departamento San Salvador. Pedro vive en con su esposa y sus cuatro hijos todos menores de edad y estudiantes. Pedro posee su pequeña empresa llamada ‘‘Peypa Sport’’ donde confeccionan variedad diseños  deportivos, Pedro genera empleo aproximadamente para siete familias  quienes dependen del éxito y duración del negocio de Pedro. En esta oportunidad el esta solicitando este crédito para abastecerse de telas que le permitan aumentar su  producción en las prendas que se elaboran en el taller.
texts.en:
Pedro Armando O. is a 36-year-old man who lives in the Apopa Municipality of the department of San Salvador. He lives with his wife and 4 school age children. Pedro owns a small business called “Peypa Sport,” in which he makes a variety of sports apparel. He generates work for approximately 7 families, who depend on the success and duration of Pedro’s business. At this time, he is requesting a loan so that he can stock up on fabric to increase production of the apparel that is made in his garment factory.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase material

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana sells clothing at the central market in Melitopol city. She has been in this business for 12 years. Her kiosk is located in a good spot at the market that attracts many customers. Her net profit is 3,500 UAH per month.

Tatyana is divorced with two children. All these years, her business has been the only source of income for the family. She lives with her daughter in their own house. Tatyana would like to borrow 10,500 UAH to increase her clothing assortment. She hopes to generate additional income to spend on the upcoming wedding of her daughter.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of clothing inventory

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica A. is a woman who believes in hard work and determination. It’s not easy to be a wife and mother with limited resources for food and the other needs of her children. Veronica is a 37-year-old mother of three boys, and she is happily married to Teofilo, who is a 43-year-old fisherman. She lives in a remote island village outside the town of Binangonan, in the province of Rizal in the Philippines.

Her husband is a fisherman and has a meager income, and she wants to help him grow his income. In 2007 she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. She hoped for access to capital to start a business, and ASHI provided her loans. She carefully used them as capital on her fish cage business, and her husband has also partnered with her.

The business provides good income for Veronica and her family. Now on her fourth loan, she proposes a loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos to pay for 2 bundles of fish nets, nails, bamboos, assorted fingerlings, transportation, and labor expenses. They will cultivate the fingerlings in her fish cages until they are ready to harvest.

Veronica believes that her business will grow. She dreams of expanding it to construct additional fish cages, and of sending all of her children to school until they finish college. She believes that with the poor situation of the Philippines, the wealth that she can leave to her children is knowledge.

loans.use: To purchase fish nets, supplies, fingerlings, transportation, and labor expenses

loans.name: Amerina

texts.en:
Amerina D. is a native of the remote island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 43 years old and married to Joselito who is a fisherman and 38 years old. She is a mother to an only son James Michael who is 3 years old. In her village, people are busy in looking for living. You cannot see malls, and other luxurious and tempting establishments.
In 2006, she joined ASHI(Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines with aspirations of bringing hope for her family to start a business of her own. Her previous loans was used by her husband as her business partner as rolling capital in making boats. Until now they are still making boats when there are orders but not now their primary business. Just more than a year ago, she shifted her business into fishing with fish cage. And it brings her good income. Her husband is also her business partner. They found it to be profit -sounded.
Now on her  4th loan, she proposes a loan of 20,000 pesos as additional capital for her fish cage business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for  2 bundles of fish nets, 60 pieces of bamboos, fingerlings, transportation and labor costs.
The fingerlings will be cultured in the fish cage until it will be ready to harvest. They will sell fishes in the market and sometimes will go directly to their fish cage to buy fish. She believes that her business will grow and she dreams of putting-up additional fish cages for bigger income. She also aspires of sending her child to school until he finish college and find job. Also, she dreams of having durable and spacious house someday.

loans.use: To pay for  2 bundles of fish nets, 60 pieces of bamboos, fingerlings, transportation and labor costs.

loans.name: Cécile

texts.fr: Cécile est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Cécile vend de piment en détail et en gros. En effet, Cécile vend le piment en gros sur commande aux restaurateurs, aux gérants de maquis et aux vendeurs en détail. Pour ses ventes en détail, Cécile expose le piment devant sa maison dans une baraque. Cécile a déjà bénéficié d’un premier crédit de la part de ALIDé pour cette activité. Cécile a bien remboursé ce crédit et sollicite un deuxième crédit pour renforcer son capitale en vue de répondre efficacement à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Cécile is married and the mother of 4 children. She sells hot peppers, both retail and wholesale. In fact, Cécile sells the hot peppers wholesale on order to restaurant owners, managers of chop bars, and to retailers. For her own retail sales, Cécile displays the hot peppers in a shed in front of her house. Cécile has already received a first loan from ALIDé for this business. Cécile has reimbursed this loan correctly and is asking for a second loan to bolster her working capital so as to respond appropriately to the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 6 sacks of hot peppers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy rice.wheat flour.sugar and salt

loans.name: Melita

texts.en:
Melita D. C. is a 52-year-old mother to three. She is a native of the island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She ihusbandzs happily living with some of her children and with her husband Napoleon who is a fisherman and is 52 years of age.
She dreams of getting out from the spiral of poverty. In 2006, she joined ASHI(Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines with hope of having access to capital to start a business. Before, she and her husband are partners in their business the bamboo set making. But considering their age, the business is quite tiring and laborious. When she received her first loan from ASHI, she constructed a fish cage in the lake. That was four years ago already. Now her business is getting bigger and brings her good income.
Now on her 4th loan, she proposes a loan of 18,000 pesos as additional capital for her fish cage business. The loan will be used to pay for 2 fish cages, renovation and repair of her other fish cages, 30 pieces of bamboos and labor expenses.
She is looking forward that with the trend of fishing as main source of income in the island is in demand; her business will grow and will bring her enough income for her family. She dreams of sending her younger children to school until they finish college.

loans.use: To pay for 2 fish cages, renovation and repair of her other fish cages, 30 pieces of bamboos and labor expenses.

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two children. She sells small home products such as tea pots, table lights, batteries for clocks, etc. Her business has three locations in a small open market, near a factory. The factory workers can buy what they need after work. Since Irina sells inexpensive items, she has clients nearly all the time. Irina has many repeat clients, and a wise discount policy.

Irina would like to borrow 12,100 UAH to purchase new inventory for her business. Irina has used micro loans in the past and considers them very helpful for her business development.

loans.use: To purchase new inventory

loans.name: Mrs. Srey Sokh Ny Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-eight people living in Sdao Kanlaeng village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan group, and they will use the loan for various purposes.

Mrs. Srey Sokh N. is the 30-year-old village bank president. She is a fried-banana seller. She is also a farmer who rents a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because her field is infertile and has a lot of insects to damage the crop. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides to support the rice field.

Mrs. Srey Sokh N.’s husband, Mr. Kung Vutha, works in a restaurant. The couple has two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides to support her rice field

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy O. is a seamstress and also sells fabrics and sewing materials at Elmina. Dorothy has received tertiary.  She is single parent and has a child. Dorothy has been selling fabrics since 2002. She is responsible for paying of her child’s school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more sewing materials and fabrics in larger quantities to resell at the market. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save toward building a house.

loans.use: er loan will be used to buy more sewing materials and fabrics in larger quantities to resell at the market.

loans.name: Chandy's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Chandy P. is a group leader of five members who all live in Ta Non village in Takeo province. She is a weaver who makes cloths. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more silks and raw materials to make more to support her customers. Her husband, Mr. Siem Chandy, is a hard working man. This couple has four children, one of whom is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: By purchasing more silks and raw materials to make more to support her customers.

loans.name: Ravshanjon

texts.en:
A. Ravshanjon, age 24, is a very diligent and hardworking young man. In addition to his wife, he is also supporting his parents. He provides taxi services with his own car. For the last three years, this business has been the main source of income allowing Ravshanjon to improve the living conditions of his large family. As with any business, Ravshanjon's business also requires some investment from time to time. At present, his car needs some fixing. For this reason, Ravshanjon requests $900 US to purchase spare parts for his car. Ravshanjon promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all those supporting him. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To repair a taxi

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy A. operates a fufu chop bar. Fufu is a local food: she usually makes it with cassava and plantain which she cooks and pounds to get her fufu for sale at Elmina. Dorothy has received junior high school education. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer. Dorothy has been operating this bar since 1984. She helps pay for school fees and the upkeep of her home. Her loan will be used to buy more cassava, meat, plantain, and so on to operate her fufu chop bar. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy cassava, meat, plantain and so on for her fufu chop bar

loans.name: Sokha's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha K. is a group leader of four members who all live in Thuoch village in TaK. province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Saom Bros, is a construction worker. This couple has 2-hectar field of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, they face an obstacle because their field is infertile which it is a bad to affect to their crop. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Sokha K. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive. She is 21 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. 

All the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loans term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Noëlie Pulchérie

texts.fr: Noëlie Pulchérie est mariée à un polygame et est mère d'un seul garçon. Pulchérie vend des foulards de façon ambulante. Pulchérie vend aussi de l’huile d’arachide, mais sur commande aux détaillants. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Pulchérie achète ses produits. Pulchérie a déjà bénéficié d’un premier crédit de la part de ALIDé pour cette activité. Pulchérie a bien remboursé ce crédit et sollicite un deuxième crédit pour renforcer son capitale en vue de répondre efficacement à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Noëlie Pulchérie is married to a polygamist and is the mother of one boy. Pulchérie sells her scarves door-to-door. Pulchérie also sells peanut oil, but only according to orders from the retailers. It's in Dantokpa, Benin's large international market, that Pulchérie purchases her products. Pulchérie has already benefitted from her first loan with Alidé for her business. Pulchérie properly repaid her first loan and is requesting a second loan to increase her capital in order to respond efficiently to the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 5 barrels of 50 liters of peanut oil and a half roll of scarves

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
D. Mahbuba is 45 years old. Mahbuba and her husband are married for almost 25 years and raised 4 children. One of them is already married and has the children of his own who adore their grandparents. Mahbuba has been running her own small business for 14 years already. She has a place for selling items such as: soft drinks, sweets, potted goods, detergents, soap, tooth-paste and many others. She works from the 7:00 a.m. till 5:00 p.m. Mahbuba is very friendly and polite which allows her to have the clientele. Now she is requesting for 5000 Somoni that will spend for purchasing more goods for selling thus increasing the range of the products. She thanks everyone who have decided to support her.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increasing of the stock, purchasing goods for selling

loans.name: Ngoem's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngoem M. is the group leader of six who all live in Kampong village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Pech Poun, is a fisherman. He has a problem with his fishing because his boat has broken. Thus, Mrs. Ngoem M. decided to ask for a loan to fix the boat. She would use the rest of money to buy fishing nets.

Mrs. Ngoem M. is 48 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is a vegetable seller in the local market, another is a farmer and the others are attending the local school.

Two members in this group have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To fix her husband's boat and to buy fishing nets

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret A. sells fish, which she buys from fishermen at the seashore and then sends to the market to sell at Elmina. Behind her are the ovens on which she smokes her fish. Margaret has no educational background. She is single with three grandchildren. Margaret has been selling fish since 1980. She is responsible for paying the children's school fees and also pays the family's rent. Her loan will be used to buy fish in larger quantities to sell at the market. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her grandchildren.

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.ru: Гулчехра Турапова проживает в районе Руми. Возраст 42 года. Разведена, имеет 2 детей. Гулчехра живет с 2 детьми. Она более 10 лет занимается бизнесом, т.е. торговлей на рынке. В основном торгует одеждой. Кредит просит для закупа нового ассортимента и увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Gulchehra T. lives in the Rumy region. She is 42 years old. She is divorced and has two children. She lives with her two children. She has been doing business for more than ten years selling on the market. She sells mostly clothing. She is asking for a loan to buy a new assortment and increase turnover.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new assortment

loans.name: Abdurauf

texts.en:
H. Abdurauf sells confectionery like candies, cookies, pastries and fruit jelly. He is 49 years old, married and has two children. He has been in this business for three years. His income allows him to support his family – he is the only breadwinner in his family. Today, Abdurauf requests $1000 US to purchase confectionery to enlarge his range of goods. Abdurauf thanks everyone for their support and promises to repay his loan on time.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase confectionery

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
K. Mahbuba is 44 years old. She is married, and uses all the money she makes to care for her three children and provide for their education. Mahbuba has an experience of 10 years preparing and selling dried apricots. She always makes very productive use of her capital, adding inventory to her supply in a way that allows her to meet her customers' needs. She is also very polite and considerate, and her clients are always very happy with the service they receive from her. Because her business is doing so well, she is increasing her net worth month by month. Today Mahbuba requests 3000 Somoni for purchasing apricots with the purpose of drying and processing them in order increase the range of her selling goods. Mahbuba expresses her gratitude for everyone supporting her and promises to repay her loan in a timely manner.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of the apricots in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.ru: Мухаббат Шарипова проживает в районе Гиссара. Возраст 32 года. Вдова, имеет 3 детей. По специальности Мухаббат "педагог". По специальности работала более 6 лет. В данный момент она более 4 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Она в основном торгует национальными материалами и шторами. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Muhabbat S. lives in the Gissar region. She is 32 years old. She is a widow and has three children. Muhabbat's profession is a teacher. She has worked in her profession for more than six years. At this time she has been selling on the market for more than four years. She sells mostly traditional fabrics and curtains. She is asking for a loan to increase turnover.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase turnover

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther C. sells soft drinks in Elmina. Esther has a junior high school education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a farmer. Esther has been selling soft drinks since 2006. She is responsible for the upkeep of the house. 

Her loan will be used to buy more soft drinks on a wholesale basis to resell at the market. She hopes to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more soft drinks on a wholesale basis to resell at the market.

loans.name: Kanoat

texts.en:
K. Kanoat is spoken of by her clients in a very caring way. She is married and has a child. Some years ago, she decided to dedicate herself, in an ambulatory way, to selling foodstuffs and opened her grocery near her house. Due to the large demand for her typical foodstuffs, she wishes in the future to open a cafe, which will offer better and more comfortable service to the population and increase the quantity of clients. 

All of this would allow her to generate a larger income for her family, with the aim to elevate their quality of life and education. In order to carry this out, she is proposing to solicit a loan of 4,500 Somoni that will be invested in purchasing more foodstuffs for her grocery. With your help, Kanoat will be able to open her café some day and turn her wishes into reality.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi.
