Her husband, Mr. Haem Noub, a recycling collector. is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and to hire laborers to work on her rice field.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 25 year old new father who sells second-hand shoes in Gikomba market in Nairobi. He has been in this business for the past three years. John has requested his first loan of Ksh. 20,000 which will allow him to purchase shoes in bulk, thereby increasing his profits. One day, John hopes to become an importer, selling shoes to vendors like himself. He would also like to help his wife start her own business, and to buy a home for their growing family.




Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add stock of shoes

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita R. is from the village of Palacapao  Quezon Bukidnon. She is 38, married and has 7 school-aged children. Teresita plants & harvests corn for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 19 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI, which she used to expand her business. Teresita is requesting a new loan, her 4th from HSPFI, for12000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Bob's Group

texts.en: Bob K. is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is 39, married and has 2 children; one is in school. He works from Mukono central market, where he is one of the executives managing the market, and he also has a stall where he sells local chickens. Bob does not have a poultry farm but he buys chickens from farmers in Busoga, Kayunga, and from western Uganda, where they are a bit cheaper, so that by reselling he can make a profit. He needs a loan to buy large numbers of chickens, since this saves on transport costs and the price is lower when you buy large numbers. With the profits, Bob will be able to pay for his child’s school fees and take care of his family.

loans.use: Buying more local chickens for resale so as to make more profits.

loans.name: Gelishon

texts.en:
Gelishon is 27. He sells second-hand shoes in the Gikomba market of Nairobi. He's been in this business for 1 year; he previously sold fabric. He requests his first loan of Ksh. 20,000 to increase his stock of shoes. Gelishon would like to become an importer one day.  He sees his business as an investment for his future family. Gelishon describes himself as self-believing and social. 

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. loans.use: Add stock of shoes

Chiku started her own grocery business selling beer,soda 3 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Chiku`s second loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 400,000 Tsh in order to buy more beer,soda.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Chiku hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.name: Yemisi

texts.en: Yemisi is 49 and is married with 5 children. She has a restaurant and also sells palm oil. She is requesting a loan of N100, 000 to purchase more palm oil to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more palm oil to sell

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily is 47 years old and married with three children. She has a bakery where she bakes bread and snacks. She has been in the business for a year now. loans.name: Lara

texts.en: Lara Z. is from the village of Lurugan, Valencia City. She is 43 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Lara owns and operates a business running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Lara is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 8th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Lurn

texts.en: Mrs. Lurn S. lives in Kgnauk Pong village in Takeo province. She sells Bro Houk in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Heng Siha, owns a business which uses the rice to make wine. Now Mrs. Lurn S. decided to request a loan to buy five piglets and pig food for breeding pigs business. She hopes to increase income and improve the family living conditions with this loan. She is 32 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband and a child are presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To request a loan to buy five piglets and pig food for breeding pigs business.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul runs a boutique and beauty shop with his wife in Kayole. Paul has been in this business for the past 10 years, and previously owned a similar shop in another location. Paul is requesting his first loan of Ksh. 30,000 in order to add to his stock of beauty products and clothes. He hopes to start other businesses in the future, including a supermarket. Paul and his wife have a 4 year old child, who they hope to educate to the highest level. Paul would like to one day buy his family a good home.

loans.name: Sauda

Sauda started her own clothing business selling clothes 2 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzania shillings.

loans.name: Mekobaun A1 Group

texts.en:
Matias H. lives in Bokong Village, in the Taebenu Subdistrict, of the Kupang District of East Nusa Tenggara Province in Indonesia. In the dry season, the weather in his village is quite hot and the plants turn yellow. The road to enter the village is unsealed and bumpy, and it is about a 1 hour drive from the TLM Baun Branch Office to this village.

Matias leads a group called Mekobaun A1 Group; the group has 7 members. Matias is 34, married and has been blessed with 3 little children: Musa H. - 5 years old, Ibrahim H. - 3 years old and Alfred H. - 2 years old. 

To fulfill his family’s daily needs, Matias works hard  cultivating his farm. There are coconuts, bananas and beans and corn planted on the farm. He usually starts his day at 7.00 am and works until 12.00 pm; he returns home to have lunch and rest for 1 hour and then goes back to work until 05.00 pm. He usually takes public transport to sell his agricultural products at Oeba Market. It costs IDR 15,000 per return trip. By selling his agricultural products Matias is only able to generate small income of about IDR 50,000 to IDR 150,000 per week; it depends on which crops he can harvest from the farm. Even though Matias only generates a small income from his farm  he always tries his best to supply his family needs every day. 

Matias has a plan to renovate his house, to better meet his family needs and provide a better future for his children. For this reason, Matias is interested in joining the TLM Cattle Fattening Program. He is requesting a loan amounting IDR 3,400,000 to buy cattle to be fattened over a twelve month period. He hopes that he will be able to generate profit that can be used to buy building materials to renovate his house. The other group members of Mekobaun A1 are also requesting loans to buy cattle to be fattened. All of them hope to have a better life.

loans.use: To buy cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Mekobaun A2 Group

texts.en:
Mekobaun A2 Group is a group of eight farmers in Bokong Village, Taebenu Subdistrict - Kupang District of East Nusa Tenggara Province. Bokong Village is situated about 27 km and a two-hour drive from Kupang City. The community in this village, including the group members, leans on agricultural products to support their family lives. They also depend on animal husbandry (pigs, chickens and cows) when meeting family needs for a particular moment (e.g. they could sell their livestock to pay a child’s education fees or when one of their family members is unwell).

Most of community in Bokong Village has a background in farming. They usually sell their agricultural products, such as bananas, coconuts and beans, at Inpres Market. The challenge that the community faces in running their businesses is the lack of public transport to reach Inpres market as it only available three days a week, whereas the local market in this area only operates on Tuesdays. 

Mekobaun A2 Group is led by Petrus A., a 60-year-old farmer. Petrus is respected by the group members as he has the ability to lead and also has constructive thoughts. He was born and grew up in Bokong Village. He is married to Agustin and they have five children: Jumlina A., who is 33, graduated from University and married; Sarce, who is 29 and working in Malaysia; Becy A., who is 26 and a senior high school graduate who spends her days helping her parents on the farm; Julianus A., who is a 24-year-old junior high school graduate and motorcycle taxi driver; and Welem A. , who is 22 and in the third semester of the university.

In order to fulfill his family's daily needs, Petrus plants cassavas, corns, bananas and beans. His family is relying on the agricultural products and this is the reason why Petrus should work hard. Currently, Petrus has to finance Welem’s education at the university. Petrus also raises pigs and goats to be sold so he can pay his son’s education fees. Petrus' wife, Agustin, also helps him to generate more income by weaving cloth to be sold but the income generated by Petrus and Agustin is not enough to meet their family's needs.     

Petrus got information that TLM Foundation provides loans to assist poor farmers like him. Together with the other community members who are interested in joining the program, they formed a group to receive a loan so they can buy young cattle to be fattened over a 12-month period. Petrus is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 3,400,000 from TLM to buy young cattle. The other group members are also requesting a loan to buy young cattle. They hope the profits that will be generated in the future will help them in improving their living standard and providing a better future for their children.

loans.use: To buy cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Micheal

texts.en: Micheal is 51 years old and married with four children. He is a commercial tricycle rider. Micheal lives in Oyo State, Nigeria. He is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase another tricycle motorcycle for transport.  He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a tricycle motorcycle

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has a small shop where he sells motor-vehicle spare parts. Peter has been in this business for the past 15 years. He previously worked in a petrol station. Peter is requesting a third loan of Ksh. 80,000 to increase his stock of spare parts.

Peter is married and has seven children and eight grandchildren. While his family used to live in the Rift Valley, after the post-election violence in Kenya, Peter was forced to relocate his entire family to Nairobi. He hopes to use the profits from his growing business to build his family a home. Peter describes himself as humble, determined and social.

loans.name: Immaculate's Group

texts.en: Immaculate T. is the leader of this lending group in Ibanda. She is 28 years old and married with 2 children who attend primary school. She is a hardworking and determined lady with a bar business in the Bisheshe trading center.  She has been running this business for one year and her best selling point is making good and classy drinks.  She is now seeking a loan in order to increase her stock of beer, wine, soda, mineral water, and malwa so she can attract more and more customers, and therefore more income. The profits from this business,  in contribution with that of her husband, will continue to help Immaculate provide for her family and educate her children.

loans.use: To increase the stock of beverages for her bar.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Mrs. Anecita D. is 53 years old, married with 3 adult children, and living in barangay Ma-ao Barrio, Bago City, Negros Occidental.

Anecita grew up knowing that being in business for oneself is not an easy task - it requires a lot of hard work, long hours, discipline and enthusiasm even when things are not going as well as you'd hoped, but it could also comfortably support a family if managed well. So when her parents who previously owned the farm supplies store she now operates decided to pass on the business to her, she had mixed feelings - excited because it had the potential of providing a steady income, enough to support her family, and at the same time she was doubtful that she could make a go of it, especially as she did not have the necessary working capital to buy stock for resale.

So when a friend told her about NWTF-Project Dungganon, she grabbed the opportunity to join and gain access to a credit line that she badly needed to make her business survive. She also admits that the discipline of paying back her loans made her realize the importance and value of good financial management.

Now on her 12th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Anecita is borrowing PHP 10,000 to enable her to buy more stock for resale in her farm supplies shop.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than $1/day to realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To buy stock for her farm supplies shop.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Gloriose

texts.en:
Greetings from Kigali-Rwanda,

Gloriose M. is 36 years old, married,has five children and one dependent.

Gloriose is requesting a loan of 500,000 RWF from Vision Fianance Company. With this loan, she hopes to expand her business through purchasing more products in order to get more profits than before.

By getting more profits through the requested loan, Gloriose plans to build her family strongly and send her children at school.

loans.use: more goods

loans.name: Araceli

texts.en:
Araceli M. is from the village of Buyog Banlag, Valencia City. She is 38 years old. Araceli is married and has three grown children. Araceli owns and operates a business running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Araceli has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 11,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Araceli joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Araceli has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Araceli is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Araceli from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en: Ofelia M. of Brgy. Ma-ao, Bago City, Negros Occidental, is a 59-year-old married woman with one adult child. For the past thirty years she has owned and managed a food stall which serves a variety of meals to the local community. This business earns a respectable PHP 10,000 per month for her small family. In her own words, Ofelia says that, "The thirty years in this business has been fulfilling for me because I proved to myself, my family and other people that I could manage and even improve my life without having a College degree. I just put a lot of trust in God and I am always honest in all my business dealings. When NWTF-Project Dungganon came to our community, at first I was hesitant to join because I wasn't sure that I could afford the weekly payments, but after attending the training seminar in 2004, I knew that I could do it. Now I am proud to say that it was Project Dungganon that helped me improve my food business and allowed me to venture into other lines of business, which has greatly improved the financial stability of my family." Ofelia is now borrowing PHP 15,000 for her 14th loan so that she can have additional working capital for her diversified businesses. But most of it will be invested in her food business. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Bukola

texts.en:
Bukola is 44 years old and married with three children. She sells foodstuffs like plantain and oil, etc. and has been in the business for a long time.

Bukola is requesting the loan of N150,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Azizkhuja

texts.en: K. Azizkhuja is dedicated to agriculture and to the growing of grapes, which means that he can be around his family, helping to raise their quality of life and educate his three children. Azizkhuja has been characterized as a person who is hardworking, since he has been working in agriculture since he was very young. This kind of work requires effort, dedication and above all, strength, as it can include heavy work, meaning that people get tired quickly. In spite of this, Azizkhuja is determined to raise to the standard of living in his family, and to improve the quality of the seeds he cultivates. For this reason, he is asking for help in order to be able to receive more credit from IMON International. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Mahmud

texts.en:
Mahmud is a married man with 5 children. He is hard-working man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children, who today are working adults thanks to his example. Mahmud has worked in farming for 20 years, and is very happy with the support of IMON International, as thanks to the loans he has received he has been able to plant more crops. His plans for his family are to improve their living conditions and well being. Mahmud started this activity on his own. He plans to be able to diversify his crops. With the proceeds of the loan he will buy supplies and fertilizers for his fields, in order to obtain better production and ability to sell at a better price. Be an important part of the growth of Mahmud’s business.

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

loans.name: Mareme

texts.fr: mareme D. est parent beneficiaire de la zone de camberene depuis 2003.elle est surtout specialisee dans le commerce de tissus principalement ,de chaussures et d'autres produits divers.elle sollicite un credit de cent mille(100 000)frs pour augmenter son fond afin de mieux diversifier les produits qu'elle commercialise.son objectif est de satisfaire sa clientele d'accroitre ses benefices et de mieux participer a soutenir son mari a l'entretien de la famille.
texts.en:
Mareme D. has been a parent beneficiary in the Camberene zone since 2003. She specializes mainly in the sale of cloth, shoes, and various other products. She is seeking a loan of 100,000 CFA to increase her funds in order to better diversify the products that she sells. Her goal is to satisfy her customers, increase her profits, and better participate in supporting her husband in providing for their family.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell goods

loans.name: Armine

texts.en:
Armine M. is 41 years old and lives in Ijevan with her family. She is married and has two sons. Her husband is a motor mechanic and has his own garage. Their two sons are also employed and help to sustain the family.

Armine studied accounting in Ijevan college and later worked in a bakery in Moscow. In 1997, she returned to Armenia and found a job as a shop assistant at a poultry farm’s market stall.

Since 2002, Armine has owned her own business. Now, she sells eggs and candy in a stall that she rents at a food market. Armine is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy a consignment of eggs for her business.

loans.use: To buy a consignment of eggs for her business

Tobietha is a member of the maendeleo borrower group in Msamvu,Morogoro,she is 36 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 3 children.Her children are aged 12,7 and 3 years.she also cares for other 3 dependents.

Tobietha started her own food business selling fruits and vegetable 3 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 450,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Tobietha second loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more fruits and vegetable.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Tobietha hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.name: Azimjon

texts.en:
P. Azimjon is 37 years old and lives with his wife and their three children. Azimjon says he comes from a humble family and from a very young age, he helped his father in the fields, which is why he never finished his studies. Despite that, he grows grapes on his farming land. Azimjon comments that he is very thankful for what he has and thanks to the dedication and support from his family, he can have a dignified life and give a better life to his children. At this time, Azimjon is applying for a loan in order to buy more raw material such as: seeds, insecticides, fertilizers, chemical products, etc. that help him cultivate more.

loans.name: Felicina

texts.en:
Felicina is a 31-year-old mother of two who runs a small printing and stationery shop in Nairobi. She has been in this business for the past four years.

Felicina has requested a first loan of Ksh 20,000 in order to add to her stock of printing papers, books and mobile phone accessories. One day, she would like to be a stationery wholesaler.

On a personal level, Felicina would like to educate her children and build them a home. She describes herself as social, jovial, outgoing and diligent.


About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add to her stock of printing papers, books and mobile phone accessories

Jared is 24 years old and owns a retail kiosk in Mukuru slums of Nairobi. Jared has been in this business for 2 years, he was previously employed in a company.  He has requested his first loan of Ksh. 20,000 to increase his stock of flour, soda, rice and other products. He would like to become a supplier of soft drinks one day.  He desires to make profits out of his business and build his family a home away from Mukuru. Jared describes himself as hardworking and quiet.

texts.en:
M. Solange is 31 years old. She is married and she has five children aged 18, 16, 14, 12 and 10.

Solange owns a small shop where she sells cold drinks such as Fanta and beer. She has ten years experience in her business and she works everyday from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. She earns a monthly profit is 150,000 Rwf.

Solange is requesting her first loan of 500,000 Rwf from Vision Finance Company. With the extra profits from this loan she hopes to expand her business, get more food for her family and pay school fees of her children.
